Title: $U$ is union of $r$-balls, $\forall r<1$ $\Rightarrow$ $U$ is union of $1$-balls?
Content: If for all $r\in(0,1)$ we know that $U\subseteq\mathbb{R}^n$ can be represented as a union of open balls of radius $r$ , do we know that it can be represented as a union of open balls of radius $1$ ? This is obviously true for $n=1$ and in general case I have proven that a dense subset of $U$ can be represented as a union of open balls of radius $1$ . Is the hypothesis true for all $n$ in the original, stronger, form? EDIT: I assume the Euclidean, i.e. $\ell^2$ norm, but if you have results with any other norm or metric they are welcome!
AcceptedAnswer: It seems that the property is true in dimension 2. Let $U$ a non-empty open strict subset of $\mathbb R^2$ that is a union of open balls of radius $r$ for all $r\in(0,1)$ . Part 1: there is always a center nearby For all $x\in U$ , there exists a sequence $(c_n)$ in $U$ such that $x\in B(c_n,1-1/n)\subset U$ . As a bounded sequence in $\mathbb R^2$ , it has an accumulation point $c$ and it is easy to see that $B(c,1)\subset U$ (using triangular inequality), but $x$ might be on its boundary. Note $C=\{c\in U:B(c,1)\subset U\}$ . Let $x_0$ be such a point in $U$ outside all ball of radius 1 in $U$ . Part 2: outsiders must be surrounded If $x_0$ is not in the convex hull of the intersection of $C$ and the closed ball $\overline B(x_0,1)$ , then there exists a line $d$ that separates them. Using its equation $\langle x-x_0,v\rangle=-1$ , there exists a sequence $(c_n)$ such that $y_n=x_0+\frac 1nv\in \overline B(c_n,1)\subset U$ but these centers must lay on the half plane given by $\langle c_n-x_0,v\rangle\ge 0$ (not containing $d$ ) hence the same holds for any accumulation point on the semi-circle of center $x_0$ and radius 1, which is contradictory. Part 3: the only way out is right in the middle By Caratheodory's theorem, $x_0$ lies in a triangle whose vertices are in $C\cap\overline B(x,1)$ . Precisely, $x_0$ is the circumcenter of this triangle. If $x_0$ belongs to the interior of this triangle, then the open ball of radius 1 around the orthocenter $H$ satisfy $x_0\in B(H,1)\subset \bigcup_{i=1}^3 B(c_i,1)\subset U$ (by isogonal conjugation), which is contradictory. So $x_0$ is the middle of a segment $[c_1,c_2]$ of length 2 between two centers in $C$ . Part 4: four exterior points blocks the balls Since we cannot move any radius 1 ball closer to $x_0$ , for all $i\in\{1,2\}$ there exists a chord between elements in $U^{\mathrm c}$ on $S(c_i,1)$ that intersects the segment $[c_i,x_0]$ . Otherwise, we could separate the segment and $U^{\mathrm c}\cap S(c_i,1)$ by a line and move the ball in the direction of a normal vector of the line, to attain $x$ . These two chords are the opposite edges of a non-self-crossing quadrilateral. Part 5: the stone was a diamond Since $U$ is open, there exists $r>0$ such that $B(x_0,r)\subset U$ . The points in the intersection $I$ of this ball and the perpendicular bisector of $[c_1, c_2]$ (and distinct of $x_0$ ) must be at distance less or equal to 1 to the center of a unitary ball in $U$ . But such a ball cannot contain $x_0$ nor the ends of the chords, so its center $c$ must be outside the balls around $c_1$ and $c_2$ , and reach the points in $I$ through the other sides of the quadrilateral. Let $(x_n)$ be a sequence in $I\setminus\{x_0\}$ converging to $x_0$ from both sides in $I$ . Then there two (symmetric) accumulation points $c_3$ and $c_4$ , giving a rectangle $c_1c_3c_2c_4$ . Therefore the chords are diameters and the quadrilateral formed by exterior points is a lozenge with two sides parallel to $[c_1,c_2]$ . Conclusion The center of each side of the lozenge is in $C$ , so the union of the four corresponding unitary balls contains a unitary ball containing $x_0$ (with a center on the largest diagonal).
